en: This entry isn’t going to start with good news or bad news, but with weird news. Two pages have been torn out from this journal, the two pages after the last entry. You didn’t do it, and you didn’t write in them either because you me us we are still sane. Two blank pages gone.
zh: 今天的日記不會以好消息或壞消息開始，而是以奇怪的消息開始：日記本中有兩頁被撕掉了，就在上一篇的后兩頁，這並不是你乾的，何況你在那兩頁上什麼也沒有寫，你還清醒得很。

en: She wants you to think you wrote an entry and can’t remember it, for which there seems no motive. Or she found the journal, was reading it, and spilled something on those pages and had to tear them out.
zh: 只有可能是桑德拉撕掉的，要麼她覺得你寫了日記，但是不記得了，不過可能性不大；要麼她找到了日記本，閱讀的時候不小心把什麼東西濺在頁面上，只好撕下來。

en: It means being more careful now about leaving the journal out.
zh: 這意味著你得更加小心了，不要把日記本落在了別的地方。

en: Eva took you to lunch yesterday. It was just the two of you, which is something you hardly ever get to do.
zh: 昨天，伊娃帶你去吃午飯，只有你們兩個人，這樣的機會倒很難得。

en: She took you to a restaurant that has a view of the Avon river out one side, and the hills out the other.
zh: 她帶你到了一家餐廳，在那兒，一邊可以欣賞艾馮河的風光，另一邊可以看到綿延不絕的小山。

en: Her friend is a chef there, and she prepared a special lunch that wasn’t on the menu, one she was working on to add within the coming weeks.
zh: 她的朋友是那裡的廚師，她精心準備了幾道菜單上沒有的佳肴，準備在未來幾個星期作為新品推出。

en: You didn’t talk much about the future with Eva, or about the wedding, instead you chatted about her music, she told you some more stories of her big trip overseas, she told you that one of her friends from school was having a baby, and that having a family is something she and Rick have been talking about.
zh: 她臉上一直洋溢著燦爛的笑容，說了很多祝福的話。你和伊娃誰也沒有說什麼，沒有談起她的將來、婚禮，而是聊起她的音樂，她便跟你說起海外旅行的趣聞，說她的一個同學要生寶寶了，說她和瑞克一直在談論組建家庭。

en: You asked if she was pregnant, and she laughed, and said no, not yet, but maybe in a couple of years.
zh: 你問她是不是懷孕了，她笑了，說沒有，還沒有，也許再過一兩年。

en: She told you that before she started writing song lyrics, she had been thinking of trying to write fiction. Just short stories. Not the kind of stuff that Henry Cutter comes up with, but stories based on slice-oflife moments she had seen when traveling, moments that eventually got turned into music.
zh: 她說她開始創作歌詞之前曾考慮過寫小說，不過不是像亨利·卡特寫的那些犯罪小說，而只是一些短篇小說，基於她旅行時的所見所聞，寫一些反映現實生活的故事，但那些所見所聞結果變成了歌詞。

en: She said she’d love some feedback, and you know she’s doing this for you, not for her, but to be asked was such a thrill.
zh: 你知道她這樣做都是為了你，而不是為了她自己，但她這樣要求你，還是讓你很激動。

en: “How about a surprise party?” Eva suggested.
zh: 「驚喜派對怎麼樣？」伊娃提議。

en: Your own writing, by the way, is going well.
zh: 順便說一下，你的創作也進展得很順利。

en: You sent the revised edition of The Man Goes Burning to your editor this morning.
zh: 今天上午，你把《燃燒的男人》的修改稿發給了你的編輯。

en: It was, it turned out, a lot of work. The book is about a firefighter who is also an arsonist who falls in love with a fellow firefighter, and burns down buildings just so he can work with her, with the ultimate goal of being able to save her life.
zh: 這真是一本耗費了你太多精力的書，小說描寫的是一個消防隊員——同時也是個縱火犯——愛上了自己的女同事，他燒毀了好幾幢大樓，只是想有機會和她一起工作，以贏得她的芳心，最後再來個英雄救美。

en: You ended up introducing a new character, which has really helped—a guy by the name of Nicholas, and Nicholas brings a whole new element to the story, some heart and depth that was lacking before.
zh: 你在修訂時添加了一個新角色，這個叫尼古拉斯的人為故事帶來新的元素，彌補了作品在情感和深度上的不足。

en: Nicholas is a punk teenager accused of an armed robbery, and while in a holding cell at the police station he is severely beaten and raped and almost dies, and of course Nicholas never committed the robbery at all.
zh: 尼古拉斯是個被指控武裝搶劫的朋克少年，在警局牢房裡他受到毒打、強|暴，差點兒丟掉小命。

en: He uses what little money he is given in compensation to put himself through law school—so all of that is in the past, and now your main character, the arsonist, uses a lawyer when he becomes a suspect after the woman he loves disappears.
zh: 不過，尼古拉斯是無辜的，他靠著那一點兒少得可憐的賠償金讀完了法學院。不過，所有這些都發生在過去。現在你的主角縱火犯，在他所愛的女人失蹤后成為嫌疑人，他需要律師為他辯護。

en: Thank God you’ve had all this work to do because really you’ve just been able to stay out of the way, which is probably the best gift you can give your family.
zh: 感謝上天，繁重的工作是你可以給家人們的最好禮物了。

en: The wedding is less than five weeks away and you can’t wait until it’s in the rearview mirror.
zh: 婚禮還有不到五個星期了，簡直迫在眉睫，但你還是等不及了。

en: In five weeks you’ll have shaken off the dementia too, and maybe you can get a good chunk of book fourteen written before going on tour with book thirteen. You’re enough of a realist to know that even though you’re dodging the dementia bullet now, that doesn’t mean it still hasn’t got your name on it.
zh: 五個星期後，你應該已經擺脫了痴呆症的糾纏，等你再去巡迴推銷作品時就得帶上十四本書，而不是之前的十三本。

en: It could be twenty years away, or it could be ten.
zh: 它可能會再等二十年乃至十年就來找你的麻煩。

en: You need to keep writing for you, for your fans, for your family.
zh: 你還得繼續寫作，為了你自己，為了你的書迷，為了你的家人。

en: In saying that, there is definitely less of a need to keep writing here—why would anybody clearly not mad need to keep a Madness Journal? You barely read from it anymore anyway.
zh: 說到日記，你真的沒有必要再去寫，為什麼一個不再是狂人的人要去寫「狂人日記」呢？

en: Sandra was at work, and your neighbor, Mrs. Smith, comes over. She comes over and she is pissed off. Somebody tore all of her flowers up, and Mrs. Smith wants to know if you know anything about it.
zh: 事情是這樣的：桑德拉工作繁重，你的鄰居史密斯太太怒氣沖沖地跑了過來，說有人毀掉了她所有的花，史密斯太太想知道你是否知道這件事情。

en: You don’t know —of course you don’t—but then she says one of the neighbors said they saw you doing it—or at least somebody who looked like you.
zh: 你當然一無所知，但她說一個鄰居說他目睹是你做的，或者至少是個看起來像你的人做的。

en: You tell her no, it wasn’t you, you’re a forty-nine-year-old crime writer who has been inside writing crime all week and who, you assure her, has far better things to do than wipe out rows and rows of her roses.
zh: 你告訴她那不是你，你是一位四十九歲的犯罪小說家，整個星期都在創作小說。你向她保證，比起辣手摧花，你有更要緊的事情要做。

en: I just find it strange that Mrs. Blatch says she was sure it was you, and that she thought you were doing some gardening.
zh: 「我只是覺得奇怪，布拉奇太太說她確信那人是你，她以為你在打理花園來著。」

en: Now, Mrs. Blatch, to put things into perspective, Future Jerry, is of an age that can only be prefaced by a seven again if she reaches seven hundred.
zh: 好了，未來的傑瑞，咱們來合理地梳理整件事情。布拉奇太太七十好幾了，下次她的年紀以「七」打頭的時候就得等她七百歲了。

en: Then Mrs. Blatch is wrong, which can’t be much of a surprise, can it?
zh: 「布拉奇太太看錯了，這沒什麼稀奇的，不是嗎？

en: She is almost two hundred years old.
zh: 她都快兩百歲了。」

en: Be that as it may, Jerry, she is sure it was you and, well, there’s no real delicate way of putting this, but after our conversation the other day, it seems like you’re paying me back.
zh: 「傑瑞，儘管如此，她很肯定是你乾的，雖然沒有辦法證實，但我覺得這是我們那天談話之後，你對我的報復。」

en: What conversation?
zh: 「什麼談話？」

en: I’m working on it, and it wasn’t me that dug up your roses.
zh: 「我正在打理花園，而且不是我毀了你的玫瑰。」

en: How can you be so sure it wasn’t?
zh: 「你怎麼能這麼肯定？

en: If you’re going to accuse me of having a grudge against your garden, then next time try to have a witness who wasn’t around when fire was invented.
zh: 「要是你非要指證我毀了你的花園，下次勞煩找個靠得住的證人來。」

en: You wished her good day—you actually used those very words, straight out of a Victorian drama, then closed the door on her.
zh: 你祝她「日安」，你真真切切用了這個出自維多利亞時代的戲劇的字眼，接著你把她關在門外。

en: Good news—Nicholas is going to save your manuscript. You’re sure of it, and the book will be out next year.
zh: 好消息：尼古拉斯拯救了你的手稿，你有把握小說會在明年出版。

en: Bad news—last night you took a leak in one of the bedrooms.
zh: 壞消息：昨晚你在一間卧室里尿尿，尿到一半你才猛然意識到你是在卧室角落裡撒尿，而不是在洗手間里。

en: So this is it, Future Jerry.
zh: 就是這些，未來的傑瑞。

en: No real time to stay in touch now and not much point either.
zh: 沒有時間時時保持聯繫了，何況也沒有多大意義。

en: You’re going to dedicate your time to the wedding and to the next book.
zh: 你忙著準備婚禮，忙著創作下一本書。

en: You actually have an idea for a new novel—about a crime writer who has dementia.
zh: 你已經構思好了一部新的小說，關於一個患有痴呆症的犯罪小說家的。

en: He is starting to feel a little like his old self. Could be the motion of the car is stirring up the brain chemistry, stirring up the memories like silt from the bottom of a river.
zh: 他恍然覺得自己已經進入遲暮之年，可能是警車的顛簸刺|激了大腦化學物質，攪亂了像是沉澱在河底淤泥一樣的回憶。

en: Could be the smell of fast food and coffee that has soaked into the pores of the upholstery, taking him back to times overseas where he’s eaten in takeaway joints while pressed for time.
zh: 也有可能是浸透擴散到車裡的快餐和咖啡的氣味把他帶回到旅居海外的時光，那時，因為時間緊迫，他經常叫外賣。

en: It could be the change of environment, it could be the fresh air he got between the nursing home and the car.
zh: 還有可能是因為環境發生了變化，走出療養院到上車之前，他呼吸到了清新的空氣。

en: There are bits and pieces of his past floating to the surface. He remembers his dad drowning in the pool, he remembers meeting Sandra at university, he remembers taking his family to cities so big they made Christchurch look like a drop in a bucket.
zh: 回憶的片段不斷湧入腦海：他記得父親在游泳池溺水身亡，記得在大學與桑德拉相遇，記得帶著家人到過許多大城市，相比之下，克萊斯特徹奇這方寸之地簡直微不足道。

en: Of course there are things he can’t remember. He has no idea what he ate for breakfast.
zh: 當然，還有一些事情他記不起來了：早餐吃了什麼？

en: He can’t remember what he did yesterday, whether he watched TV or walked in the garden.
zh: 昨天做了什麼？是看電視還是在花園裡散步？他不記得最後一次看的什麼報紙，不記得最後一次擁抱妻子，不記得最後一次打的什麼電話或寫的什麼電子郵件。

en: The memories shift, they stir, some of them settle, some of them disappear.
zh: 記憶在遊動，在翻滾，有些沉澱了下來，有些消失無蹤。

en: He says nothing to the policemen—Nurse Hamilton was very specific about that. Say nothing.
zh: 他什麼也沒有對警察說，這是漢密爾頓護士特別關照過的。

en: Ask for a drink if you’re thirsty, ask for the bathroom if you need to go, but that’s all.
zh: 如果你渴了，就要飲料喝；如果想上廁所，就要求去洗手間。

en: They spoke in front of the two detectives, Detective Mayor and Detective Something Else, and then she told them not to engage Jerry in conversation until his lawyer arrived.
zh: 他們倆是當著兩個警察的面說這些話的，警察梅厄和某某，她告訴他們不要急著跟傑瑞談話，要等他的律師來。

en: That trying begins five miles closer to town, Mayor adjusting himself in the passenger seat and tilting the mirror so he can look at Jerry.
zh: 距離市區還有十公里左右，梅厄在副駕駛座上挪動了一下身子，調整了一下後視鏡的角度，這樣他就可以看著傑瑞了。

en: “So you’re a writer, huh?”
zh: 「你是個作家，是吧？」

en: Jerry doesn’t answer. He’s thinking about Sandra, and whether Nurse Hamilton has called her already.
zh: 傑瑞沒有回答，他在想桑德拉，不知道漢密爾頓護士是否已經打電話給她了。

en: No doubt Sandra will want to come down, either to support him, or to prove divorcing him was the best decision she’s made of late.
zh: 桑德拉肯定會過來的，要麼給予他支持，要麼告訴他和他離婚是明智之舉。

en: He can see Mayor’s eyes and nose in the mirror, but nothing else.
zh: 他可以在後視鏡里看到梅厄的眼睛和鼻子，再無其他。

en: There’s nothing between the front and the backseat to stop Jerry from tousling the man’s hair. Or trying to strangle him.
zh: 前座和後座之間沒有任何遮擋物，傑瑞完全可以毫無障礙地揪著那人的頭髮，或者掐死他。

en: “Come on, this is us just shooting the breeze,” Mayor says, “ain’t that right, Chris?”
zh: 「好了，我們只是在閑聊。」梅厄說，「是不是啊，克里斯？」

en: “Gotta do something on the ride back,” Chris says, “otherwise it’s a pretty boring trip.”
zh: 「回去的路上總得做點什麼。」克里斯說，「不然就太無聊了。」

en: “We’re just chitchatting here,” Mayor says.
zh: 「我們只是在閑聊罷了。」

en: “Think of it like we’re meeting for the first time at a barbecue and we’re having a couple of beers.
zh: 梅厄說，「就像我們第一次見面那樣，吃著燒烤，喝著啤酒。

en: You must get that all the time, right? Mr. Bigshot writer?
zh: 你一定還記得的，對吧，我的大作家先生？

en: You must love talking about it. So pretend we’re at that barbecue.
zh: 你肯定喜歡談這個話題的，所以假設我們在吃燒烤。

en: You write crime fiction, right?
zh: 你是寫犯罪小說的，對吧？

en: You written anything I would have read?”
zh: 不知道我讀過你寫過的沒有。」

en: “Maybe.
zh: 「也許吧。」

en: I like a good crime novel, you know?
zh: 傑瑞說。「也許吧。你知道嗎，我喜歡寫得好的犯罪小說，我喜歡懸疑。

en: I like a good mystery.
zh: 我喜歡解謎。

en: Your novels, are they like that?”
zh: 你的小說都是這種嗎？」

en: “I’m not . . .
zh: 「我不……我不清楚。」

en: I’m not sure,” Jerry says, and he isn’t sure.
zh: 傑瑞說，他真的不清楚。

en: “He’s not sure, you hear that, Chris?”
zh: 「他不清楚。你聽到了嗎，克里斯？」

en: “I heard it. It’s the dementia. Guy can’t even remember his own stories.”
zh: 「我聽見了，這就是老年痴呆症，一個人甚至不記得他自己。」

en: “But you remember the characters, right?”
zh: 「但是，你還記得書中的人物，對吧？」

en: Mayor asks. “You remember killing them. Is that why you write?
zh: 梅厄問，「你還記得怎麼殺死了他們，這就是你為什麼要寫作嗎？

en: You write about these things because it’s an outlet for you, you figure writing is better than doing the actual crimes?
zh: 你可以藉此發泄，你是不是覺得寫這些東西比真的犯罪過癮？

en: I’ve always wondered that about you guys.”
zh: 我一直搞不懂你們這些人是怎麼想的。」

en: Jerry doesn’t answer him.
zh: 傑瑞沒有回答。

en: “The way I see it, I’ve always figured a guy who writes the kind of books you write, well, there must be something wrong with him, something sick and twisted inside.
zh: 「依我看，寫這些東西的人肯定有病，腦子不清楚。

en: Why else come up with all that stuff?”
zh: 要不然怎麼會想出那些東西來？」

en: Jerry doesn’t answer him. “The shit we see every day, and we see a lot of shit, don’t we, Chris?”
zh: 「這種人渣我們每天都能看見，我們見過很多，對吧，克里斯？」

en: “Sure we do,” Chris says.
zh: 「是的。」克里斯說。

en: “It’s deep,” Chris says, “and it’s never going away.”
zh: 「他們藏得很深。」克里斯說，「但不會消失。」

en: “If you saw what we saw, I mean, how does a guy like you take what slowly kills us on the inside and turn it into entertainment?
zh: 梅厄表示同意，「如果你能看到我們看到的，我的意思是說，像你這樣的人怎麼能在內心把我們慢慢處死，然後再寫下來變成一種娛樂？

en: Do you turn on the radio and hear about some poor kid tossed into a dumpster with her throat and panties all torn and you think to yourself, well now, that’ll make a good story?”
zh: 你是不是會打開收音機，聽到可憐的女孩脖子上套著繩索，內褲被扯掉，心裏就想，這會成為一個很好的故事素材？」

en: Jerry wants to say nothing, but he can’t help himself.
zh: 傑瑞本不想說什麼的，但他抑制不住自己。

en: “It’s not like that,” he says, getting angry.
zh: 「不是這樣的。」他的語氣很憤怒。

en: He knows writing isn’t like that.
zh: 他知道寫作不是這樣的。

en: He knows it because of the moving car, the swirling brain chemistry, like silt in a stream.
zh: 因為疾馳的警車，他大腦里發生著像激流中的淤泥一般翻湧著的化學反應，他知道寫作不是這樣的。

en: “Do you get off on it? You’re just sitting by the TV, waiting for the news to come on every day, sitting with your notepad waiting to be inspired by somebody else’s tragedy?”
zh: 你帶著筆記本，每天守在電視機前等著新聞，等著別人的悲劇激發你的靈感？」

en: “Of course not.”
zh: 「不是這樣的。」

en: “Do the messier ones give you better ideas?”
zh: 「是不是整天活得雞飛狗跳的人能給你更多的想法？」

en: Jerry doesn’t answer him. There’s nothing you can say to somebody who already has their mind made up.
zh: 傑瑞沒有回答，跟那些先入為主的人沒有什麼好說的。

en: “You make your money by selling crime,” Mayor says. “Make more than we do by solving it.”
zh: 「你出售犯罪事件掙錢，」梅厄說，「然後解決它，結果比我們掙的還多。」

en: “And without crime you’d be out of a job,” Jerry says.
zh: 「沒有犯罪你會失去工作。」

en: “The suit you’re wearing, the house you live in, the food you give your children, all of that is bought and paid for on the back of other people’s suffering.”
zh: 傑瑞說，「你穿的衣服、住的房子、給孩子吃的飯、買的一切，這些都建立在他人的痛苦之上。」

en: “Ooh, you hear that, Chris?”
zh: 「哇哦，克里斯，你聽見了嗎？」

en: “So tell us, Jerry,” Mayor says.
zh: 「那你跟我們說說，傑瑞。」

en: “Tell us how much real-life sad stories inspire you.”
zh: 梅厄說，「跟我們說說現實生活中的悲慘故事是怎麼激發你的靈感的。」

en: Jerry looks between the two men at the road ahead, staring out at a logging truck they’re following, the load swaying side to side as it races down the motorway at sixty miles an hour.
zh: 傑瑞透過兩人之間的空隙看著前方的道路，他們正尾隨著一輛測井工程車，警車以每小時一百公里的速度行駛在高速公路上，車廂左右搖擺。

en: “Like I said, it’s not like that.”
zh: 「我說過了，不是這樣的。」

en: “No? Then what is it like?”
zh: 「不是這樣的？那又是怎麼樣的？」

en: “You wouldn’t understand.”
zh: 「你不會明白的。」

en: “You hear that, Chris?”
zh: 「克里斯，你聽見了嗎？」

en: Mayor asks, and Jerry hates how he keeps doing that, how he keeps running everything past his partner.
zh: 梅厄問。傑瑞很討厭他這麼做，什麼事都用這種語氣跟同伴說。

en: “He doesn’t think I can understand.”
zh: 「他認為我不能理解。」

en: “I think you can understand,” Chris says.
zh: 「我認為你能理解。」

en: “Our friend back there just needs to give you a chance.”
zh: 克里斯說，「我們坐在後邊的朋友需要給你一次機會。」

en: “I think you’re right,” Mayor says.
zh: 「我覺得你說得對。」

en: “What do you say, Jerry?
zh: 梅厄說，「你說什麼，傑瑞？

en: Want to give me a chance?
zh: 你想給我一個機會嗎？

en: I’m no crime writer, and I hear the cops in your books don’t do much other than scratch their asses and sniff their fingers, but how about you explain it to me?”
zh: 我不是犯罪小說家，但我聽說你寫的書中警察都是吃乾飯的，除了摳摳老繭，聞聞手指，其他什麼也不會。你能給我解釋一下嗎？」

en: It’s something he used to get a lot.
zh: 這種事他遇到的多了。

en: He remembers that—it was a question journalists always used to throw his way.
zh: 他還記得記者也老是問這樣的難題。

en: So you’re fascinated by crime.
zh: 「所以，犯罪總是令你痴迷不已。」

en: No, he’s not—he likes crime writing, but not crime, and how many times has he pointed out the two are very different animals?
zh: 不，他不是的，他喜歡寫犯罪小說，而不是真的要去以身試法，他已經多次指出這兩者之間的不同。

en: It’s like thinking people who watch war movies must love war.
zh: 這就像是認為愛看戰爭題材電影的人一定鼓吹戰爭一樣。

en: Over the years he’s turned down interviews for TV and radio where reporters have wanted his perspective on a current homicide, always feeling how inappropriate it would be, how hurtful it would be for the family, having an author throw in his two cents just for some publicity.
zh: 多年來，他曾無數次拒絕電視和廣播台的採訪，記者們一直想聽聽他對於現行殺人犯的看法，他覺得這不合時宜，會給被害人的家人帶來多麼大的傷害：有個作者把他們的不幸公之於眾以此來換取稿費。

en: “Crime has been around forever too,” Mayor says.
zh: 「犯罪也無處不在。」梅厄說。

en: “It doesn’t work that way, and people who think it does don’t know what the hell they’re talking about,” Jerry says, and right now he is very switched on.
zh: 「不是這樣的，會這麼想的人根本就不知道自己到底在說什麼。」傑瑞說，他覺得此刻神志清醒，好像又回到了原來的自己。

en: Right now he feels like the man he used to be. Not all the details are there, and he still can’t figure out what he did to make Sandra divorce him, but there’s more there than what there’s been of late, he’s sure of that.
zh: 但還有些片段有些模糊不清，他還是不知道他到底做了什麼讓桑德拉要和他離婚。

en: “People don’t read my books and think, Hey, that’s a great idea, let me try that,” he says, and then he realizes that Mayor probably knows all this already and is just trying to bait him into slipping up.
zh: 「人們讀過我的書後不會想：這想法不錯，也讓我試試。」

en: He should shut up, he knows that, but he carries on. “People don’t wake up and become killers because of a piece of fiction.
zh: 他知道他應該就此打住，但他還是接著說：「人們不會因為看了一篇小說就成為殺人兇手。

en: People have to be messed up first. By the time our books come along there’s already something seriously wrong with them.”
zh: 人們首先會心懷惡意，等到我的書出版時，他們心中鬼胎已經深種了。」

en: “So you don’t mind your books lighting that fuse?”
zh: 「那麼，是你的書點燃導火索，這樣說你不會介意吧？」

en: Jerry takes a deep breath the same way he used to when people would ask this during an interview. Then he stares at Mayor.
zh: 就像人們在交談中問到這個問題那樣，傑瑞深吸了一口氣，然後他兩眼直勾勾地盯著梅厄。

en: “Let’s blame the writer.
zh: 「那我們就控訴作家們去吧。

en: Let’s not blame society, the justice system, the mental health system, the economy, let’s not try to shorten the gap between the rich and the poor, let’s not blame education and people slipping through the cracks, and minimum wage not covering the cost of living and forcing people to do things they normally wouldn’t, let’s not blame the twenty-four-hour news cycle instilling fear into everybody, or how easy it is to get a gun, let’s blame the author, it’s his fault, lock all the authors up and there’s your world peace,” he says, and he can feel his heart rate climbing, can feel something pulsing in his forehead, can feel the old Jerry returning.
zh: 不要怪社會、司法、醫療、經濟，別再徒勞地縮小貧富差距，別再責怪教育，不要在乎人民的關注度夠不夠，不要抱怨最低工資不能維繫基本生活，不要強迫人們做他們辦不到的事情，不要指責二十四小時新聞向人們灌輸社會的陰暗面，或者太容易搞到槍支。讓我們責怪作者，犯罪是他的錯，把所有的作家都拘押起來，你的世界就和平了。」他感到心跳加速，額頭上青筋暴起，彷彿原來的傑瑞回到了身體里。

en: Mayor doesn’t answer.
zh: 梅厄沒有回答。

en: Jerry can’t tell if he’s scored a point or if Mayor’s just thinking about his next question.
zh: 傑瑞不知道是不是因為自己佔了上風，還是說梅厄在思考他的下一個問題。

en: Then it comes. “Let me ask you something else,” Mayor says, and his tone is the same, just casually shooting the breeze. “You ever think that a crime writer could outsmart the police?
zh: 果然，他的問題接踵而來：「我問你一件事，」梅厄說，他的語氣和剛才一樣，如同閑聊一般，「你有沒有想過，犯罪小說家會比警察更聰明？

en: You ever think to yourself if anybody could kill somebody and get away with it, it would be you?”
zh: 你有沒有想過，如果有人殺了人並且逍遙法外，會不會那個人就會是你？」

en: “A guy like you, I bet you think you could do it, huh?
zh: 他沒有回答，梅厄接著說：「我敢打賭，像你這樣的人，總以為你能做到這一點，是嗎？

en: I bet you think you could contaminate a crime scene in a way so nobody would even know you were there.”
zh: 我敢打賭，你認為你可以偽造犯罪現場，所以不會有人知道你到過那裡。」

en: Jerry doesn’t say anything.
zh: 傑瑞什麼也沒有說。

en: “So how would you go about it?
zh: 梅厄說，「那麼你會怎麼做呢？

en: How would one of your characters go about it?”
zh: 你書中的人物又會怎麼做呢？」

en: “I don’t know.”
zh: 「我不知道。」

en: “You don’t know.
zh: 「你不知道？

en: Come on, Grey, you’re the writer here.
zh: 拜託，格雷，你是個作家！

en: Would you wipe away the fingerprints?”
zh: 你會擦去指紋嗎？」

en: “I guess.”
zh: 「我想我會的。」

en: “Of course you would.
zh: 「你當然會的，也會在你書中找到的。

en: What else?
zh: 還有什麼？

en: You’d use bleach, right?
zh: 你還會用漂白劑，對不對？

en: You’d pour bleach all over the body?”
zh: 你會對屍體用漂白劑吧？」

en: “Something like that.”
zh: 「差不多吧。」

en: “Maybe set fire to the place?”
zh: 「還會放火燒掉現場？」

en: “Something like that.”
zh: 「差不多吧。」

en: “Hide the body somewhere?”
zh: 「把屍體藏匿起來？」

en: “Maybe.”
zh: 「也許吧。」

en: “All the books you’ve written, all the research, all the movies you’ve watched—I bet you have quite a knowledge of police forensics.”
zh: 「所有你寫的書、進行的研究、看過的電影，我敢打賭，你非常清楚警察取證的程序。」

en: Jerry says nothing.
zh: 傑瑞沒有搭腔。

en: “So tell me, what would it take?” Mayor asks.
zh: 「那你告訴我，需要怎麼樣？」

en: “What would it take, do you think, to get away with murder?”
zh: 梅厄問，「你認為需要怎麼樣，罪人才能逃脫法網？」

en: Instead of answering, Jerry stares at the logging truck, willing the logs to fall off the back and . . . and what?
zh: 傑瑞沒有回答，而是盯著前面的測井工程車，盼著車上裝的東西脫落下來，這會發生什麼呢？

en: He doesn’t know. Something. Not crush their car, but something.
zh: 他不知道，不會撞到他們的車，但肯定會發生什麼的。

en: “See, this girl we were asking you about earlier, Belinda Murray,” Mayor says, “her murder is still unsolved.
zh: 「想一想我們早些時候問過你的女孩——貝琳達·穆雷，」梅厄說，「她的謀殺案至今還沒有偵破。

en: So somebody pretty clever got away with it, don’t you think?”
zh: 一個非常狡猾的殺人犯殺人之後逃之夭夭，你覺得是這樣嗎？」

en: “Maybe they were just lucky,” Jerry says.
zh: 「也許他只是運氣比較好罷了。」傑瑞說。

en: “You ever have characters who commit a crime and then can’t remember doing it?”
zh: 「你書里有沒有人犯了罪，結果自己反而不記得了？」

en: “I don’t want to talk anymore,” Jerry tells him.
zh: 「我不想再說什麼了。」

en: It’s what Nurse Hamilton said to do—say nothing.
zh: 傑瑞說，這是漢密爾頓護士告誡過他的：什麼也不要說。

en: He’s already said too much as it is.
zh: 他已經說得太多了。

en: “Come on, we’re just getting warmed up here.”
zh: 「聊聊嘛，我們才剛剛熱身。」

en: “Making barbecue talk,” Jerry says, and he knows he shouldn’t even have said that.
zh: 「就像吃燒烤時候的閑聊。」傑瑞說，他知道他不該說這話，但他就是忍不住想跟這些人談談，想通過他們之間的相處，讓他知道他不是壞人，那麼這一切都可以真相大白。

en: They’ll know he’s not a killer.
zh: 他們會知道他不是殺人犯。

en: “Exactly. Barbecue talk. I like that.
zh: 「當然了，像吃燒烤一樣的閑聊，我喜歡。

en: You should use that in one of your books,” Mayor says.
zh: 你也應該在你的書中用用這個橋段。」

en: “Let’s say you’ve got a character who says he can’t remember killing somebody. How does that go?”
zh: 梅厄說，「比方說，你塑造了一個人物，他說他不記得殺過人了，請問這該怎麼辦呢？」

en: he asks, and when Jerry doesn’t answer, Mayor answers for him. “They’re usually lying, right?”
zh: 他問，見傑瑞沒有回答，梅厄接著道，「他們肯定在說謊，對吧？」

en: “I didn’t kill that girl,” Jerry says.
zh: 「我沒有殺害那個女孩。」傑瑞說。

en: “But two days ago you said you did.”
zh: 「但前兩天你說你殺害她了。」

en: “I don’t remember saying that.”
zh: 「我不記得說過那話。」

en: “No more questions.”
zh: 「不要再問了！」

en: “Last one,” Mayor says.
zh: 「最後一個。」

en: “If you had killed her, would you know?
zh: 梅厄說，「如果你殺了她，你自己會知道嗎？

en: Would you feel it?
zh: 你能感覺到嗎？

en: I don’t mean remember it, but feel it . . . in your bones somehow?”
zh: 我的意思不是記住，而是感覺……在你內心深處？」

en: Jerry thinks about it, and it doesn’t take long to come up with an answer. “Of course I would.
zh: 傑瑞思索了一會兒：「我當然會的。

en: I might not remember it, but I would know it, and that’s how I know I didn’t hurt that woman.”
zh: 我可能不記得了，但我會感覺到。正因為如此，我才知道我沒有傷害過那個女人。」

en: “You said no more questions.”
zh: 「我說你不要再問了。」

en: “But you’re a curious guy, right?
zh: 「但你是一個好奇的人，對不對？

en: All authors must be.
zh: 所有作家都很好奇。

en: So let’s carry on, for the sake of learning.
zh: 所以我們不妨繼續下去，只為探明真相。

en: You ever killed anybody, Jerry?
zh: 你殺過人，傑瑞。

en: I don’t mean in the books, I mean in real life.”
zh: 我的意思不是說在書里，而是在現實生活中。」

en: Jerry doesn’t answer.
zh: 傑瑞沒有回答。

en: “I’ll take that as a no, because you’d remember it, right?
zh: 「你不回答，我就權當沒有，因為你會記得的，對吧？

en: And if you didn’t remember, you’d feel it in your bones.”
zh: 如果你不記得，你內心也會感覺到的。」

en: “I don’t want to talk anymore until my lawyer arrives.”
zh: 「在我的律師到來之前，我不想再說什麼了。」

en: “What about your wife?” Mayor asks.
zh: 「你妻子呢？」梅厄問。

en: “I’ll wait until she arrives too,” Jerry says.
zh: 「我也會等她來的。」傑瑞說。

en: Mayor shakes his head. “That’s not what I mean.
zh: 梅厄搖了搖頭：「我不是這個意思。

en: I mean do you remember killing your wife?”
zh: 我是問你是否還記得你殺死過你的妻子嗎？」

en: The question is confusing, and makes Jerry feel like he’s just missed part of the conversation. Did he zone out?
zh: 這個問題有些猝不及防，傑瑞覺得他錯過了某一部分對話。

en: Is his memory retreating?
zh: 他剛才走神了嗎？還是說他的記憶消失了？

en: “No, Jerry, in real life.”
zh: 「不，傑瑞，是現實生活中。」

en: Jerry shakes his head. “Of course not.
zh: 傑瑞搖了搖頭：「當然沒有。

en: How could I?
zh: 我怎麼能記得呢？

en: She’s still alive.”
zh: 她還活著呢。」

en: “She’s dead, Jerry,” Mayor says.
zh: 「她死了，傑瑞。」

en: “You killed her.”
zh: 梅厄說，「你殺死了她。」

en: “Don’t say that.”
zh: 「別胡說。」

en: “You shot her.”
zh: 「你開槍打死了她。」

en: “I said don’t say that.”
zh: 「我說了，別胡說。」

en: “Why not?
zh: 「為什麼？

en: It’s true.”
zh: 這是真的。」

en: “That’s not funny,” Jerry says, and it’s not funny, not funny, not funny, and it’s not true either, not true, and the silt is shifting, it’s shifting, and it can’t be true because he doesn’t even own a gun, and it’s like he’s been saying—he would feel it.
zh: 「這並不好笑。」傑瑞說，這並不好笑，不好笑，不好笑；這並不是真的，不是真的，不是真的。他根本就沒有槍，所以不可能是真的，就像他說的那樣，他能感覺到。

en: “It was almost a year ago. You murdered your own wife,” Mayor says, that smug look on his face, that all-knowing, I’m smarter than you look that is making Jerry start to shake with anger.
zh: 「大概在一年前，你殺了你的妻子。」

en: You can’t say you didn’t kill Belinda Murray because you’d have felt it if you did, then say you can’t remember shooting your wife when we know for a fact that you did.”
zh: 「畢竟，你會有感覺的，對吧？這是你說的。傑瑞，這就是我所說的情節漏洞。你不能說你沒有殺死貝琳達·穆雷，因為你殺死了她，而你已經感覺到了。

en: “Dennis . . .” his partner says.
zh: 「丹尼斯——」他的搭檔說。

en: “What?
zh: 「怎麼了？

en: That’s why you’re in a nursing home.
zh: 這就是為什麼你會在療養院。

en: If it’d been up to me, I’d have put you in jail, but you were deemed non compos mentis.”
zh: 要我說，我們就該把你關進監獄，但他們認為你精神不正常。」

en: “Don’t say that,” he says, and he starts slapping the sides of his face, gently, not enough to hurt, not in the beginning, then just a little harder, and a little harder again.
zh: 「夠了。」他說著，抽打起自己的臉頰來，輕輕地，不疼，接著力道開始加重，再加重，「她沒有死，她沒有死。」

en: “She’s not dead, she’s not dead,” he says, and he knows that right now he must look like the very mental patient they think he’s been pretending to be, but he doesn’t care.
zh: 他說，他知道他現在必須像個非常嚴重的精神病人，他們認為他是假裝的，但他並不在乎。

en: “I think that’s enough, Mayor,” Chris says.
zh: 「我覺得夠了，梅厄。」克里斯說。

en: “Sandra isn’t dead,” Jerry says, still slapping himself.
zh: 「桑德拉沒有死。」傑瑞說，還在抽著自己耳光。

en: “You shot her,” Mayor says, speaking louder to be heard over Jerry, and he points his top two fingers at Jerry and cocks his thumb back, turning his hand into a gun.
zh: 「你開槍打死了她。」梅厄提高嗓門說，好讓傑瑞聽到。他用中指和食指對準傑瑞，蹺起拇指，把手做成槍的模樣。

en: He reaches into the backseat and points it to within an inch of Jerry’s chest. “Bang.
zh: 他將手伸向後座，指著傑瑞的胸口，相距不過一英寸。

en: Right in the heart.”
zh: 「砰！就在心臟。」

en: “Bang.”
His name is Jerry Henry Grey Cutter and he is an author and he makes things up and he’s making this up. This isn’t real. These people aren’t real.
zh: 他的名字是傑瑞·亨利·格雷·卡特，他是位作家，他虛構故事，這些都是他虛構的，這些都不是真的，這些人都不是真的。

en: “Get off me, you crazy prick,” Mayor screams, and buries the fingers of his good hand into Jerry’s forearms, but Jerry keeps a tight hold, all while Chris swerves the car to the side of the road and brings it to a stop.
zh: 「放開我，你這個瘋子！」梅厄尖叫道，用另一隻手掐住傑瑞的手臂，但傑瑞抓得更緊了。克里斯把車子轉了個彎，停到路邊。

en: “My wife isn’t dead,” Jerry says, and the thought of it is overwhelming.
zh: 「我妻子沒有死！」傑瑞說，他滿腦子都是這個想法，「說她沒有死！

en: Say it!”
Chris leans over and tries to get Jerry to let go, then Mayor lashes out with a fist and gets Jerry in the side of the face.
zh: 克里斯靠了過來，想讓傑瑞放手，梅厄一拳頭使勁砸在傑瑞的臉上。

en: “Don’t,” Chris says.
zh: 「別。」克里斯說。

en: “He said Sandra is dead.”
zh: 「他說桑德拉死了。」

en: “He shouldn’t have said that,” Chris says.
zh: 「他不應該這麼說。」克里斯說。

en: “No, he shouldn’t have.
zh: 「對，他不應該那麼說。

en: It’s not funny.”
zh: 這並不好笑。」

en: Chris gets out of the car. He opens the back door and tells Jerry to climb out.
zh: 克里斯下車打開後門，叫傑瑞下來。

en: When he’s out, Chris tells him to turn around, then he slips a pair of handcuffs on him.
zh: 他下了車，克里斯讓他轉過身去，乾淨利落地給他戴上手銬。

en: Jerry has the feeling he’s been handcuffed before.
zh: 傑瑞恍惚覺得自己之前好像戴過手銬。

en: “Is she though?” he asks.
zh: 「可是，她是不是……」他問。

en: “Is she what?”
zh: 「她是什麼呢？」

en: Chris says.
zh: 克里斯說。

en: “Dead.”
zh: 「死了？」

en: Silence for a few seconds, then Chris starts nodding.
zh: 克里斯沉默了幾秒鐘，然後點點頭。

en: “She is, Jerry.
zh: 「她是死了，傑瑞。

en: Instead he falls down on the side of the road, his knees banging heavily into it, his hands cuffed behind him, and he tips onto his side and starts sobbing into the asphalt.
zh: 他說。傑瑞沒法上車了，他重重地摔倒在路邊，膝蓋撞在地上，身子倒向一邊。他雙手被銬著，開始哭泣起來，眼淚吧嗒吧嗒地滴在瀝青路面上。
